body:
@cjolivier01 I have implemented a simple tool to parse the profile.json which is generated by mxnet. Please kindly find it here: [https://github.com/TaoLv/mxProfileParser](https://github.com/TaoLv/mxProfileParser)
We use it to profile performance of mkldnn ops when we integrate mkldnn into mxnet. I'm just wonder if I can get more infomation like input/output shape from the profiling file in your current enhancements?

i think that will be good to make another PR. why do you think? where do
you think you’d want to put it in the source tree? i’ll try it out tomorrow.

On Mon, Jan 22, 2018 at 9:11 PM PatricZhao <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @TaoLv <https://github.com/taolv> it's a very useful tool.
> @cjolivier01 <https://github.com/cjolivier01> do you think it's necessary
> to PR this script into mxnet?
> In the further, we will add the special profile analysis for CPU MKL-DNN
> backend.
> Sorry, this is not very related to the topic and we may create a new PR to
> discuss :(
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8972#issuecomment-359678505>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AKts_dbiUWoX0Bl1MdCXYl0K4m7gy2DDks5tNWoegaJpZM4Q4hdI>
> .
>

The changes are good to me as far as I know.
But I still suggest **not** to include it as a part of v1.0.1. This PR does not bring any new feature (or more precisely, the 'feature' is not completed) but may introduce risks.
I agree with @cjolivier01 that we should make incremental changes, while I prefer to merge it after a stable release.

Thanks a lot.

We will create a new PR to share our initial ideas a little later (maybe after #8302 merged so that we can profile all data together).

Sorry for the late response. I didn't see any hangs since the upgrade, but
it would be good if we could figure out whether that specific version was
the issue.

Am 22.01.2018 9:02 nachm. schrieb "Sheng Zha" <notifications@github.com>:

@meissnereric <https://github.com/meissnereric> @asmushetzel
<https://github.com/asmushetzel>, though not high priority, it would still
be good if we rule out whether it's a bug in mxnet or not. This is why I
suggested reverting to a version prior to PR9218, so that we know for sure.

I am more concerned with the name `Indexer` and the related behavior(manually extracting Indexer and synchronize between train/valid dataset). The others LGTM now.
@Godricly Thanks. But moving my project from symbol to gluon might be a hard work.
@zhreshold thanks. @astonzhang shall we consider a different name for indexer, like the aforementioned "vocabulary"?
Thank you a lot. I upgrade mxnet and the result is right.
`_symbol` is a data member of `Module`. You can use `model._symbol` to get the symbol.
Yeah, that solved the problem. Thank you so much @reminisce !
Could you please take a look? @szha @sxjscience

Hello. Can someone help me with this? I dont understand why this commit cannot be built since the modifications are done only at python level (at a very precise place).
Thanks!
I have the same issue. Can anyone answer my stackoverflow question https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48401060/mxnet-regression-divide-by-zero-error

I found the cause of problem:

If I increase the value of 2nd parameter of Speedometer() function it works:

model.fit(train_iter, eval_iter,
            optimizer_params={'learning_rate':0.005, 'momentum': 0.9},
            num_epoch=50,
            eval_metric='mse',
            batch_end_callback = mx.callback.Speedometer(batch_size, 50))

I would like to propose the following change for class names:
TokenIndexer -> Vocabulary
Glossary -> VocabularyEmbedding
TokenEmbedding -> PretrainedEmbedding

Otherwise, having both Vocabulary and Glossary is likely confusing. Having both VocabularyEmbedding and TokenEmbedding is also likely confusing. 

Is the proposed change OK?
I think we should revise the doc to say that n is the output dimension.

VocabularyEmbedding and PretrainedEmbedding don't sound like they would inherit each other, and the concerns are unclear just based on the name. I probably won't remember which is which after a couple of weeks. Let's consider other names for those two.

How about:
TokenIndexer -> Vocabulary
Glossary -> VocabularyEmbedding
TokenEmbedding -> Embedding
OR
TokenEmbedding (no change)
CompositeEmbedding sounds more like what Glossary does.
Closing this. Will open a new PR with exception handling support.
Please see: [Exception Handling Wiki](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MXNET/Improved+exception+handling+in+MXNet)

I just got this and fixed it by, from mxnet directory, typing:
find . -type f -name "*.pyc" | xargs rm

Should we build with CMake?
yeah of course. I also wouldn't mind to close the PR and update the other PR. Just whatever solution gets the fix into the next release works for me :)

@larroy I'd prefer to keep it with normal Makefiles for the time being as that's what the other Dockerfiles are using.  I had some issues building with CMake as well.  For example cuda configuration right now is determined by the host GPU, which isn't exactly what you want when cross compiling.  We could get it to work with CMake, but since both build systems are valid I chose the traditional make.
I also met the same crash.

In fact, I think this makes it very difficult to use of int64 as a Gluon Parameter dtype because any call to initialize() will start using zeros().

Obviously, this operator should be trivial to implement.

Also, some features in minpy like [autograd](http://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/api/python/autograd/autograd.html) has been merged into MXNet and you can try that. You may also try to write your functions using [NDArray APIs](http://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/api/python/ndarray/ndarray.html) instead of relying on minpy.

Hello @gzh1991, thanks for asking this question, as I'm sure it's of interest to a few users. 

I've recently had similar results,  and can share what my measurements have shown.  To find out exactly why it's slower on your machine I recommend using nvprof to look at the perf summaries for both fp32 and fp16.

What I have noted is that fp16 requires kernel launches with typically more registers used per thread than fp32.  There's a fixed number of registers per processor in your gpu, so cuda responds to this increase by decreasing the number of threads running concurrently.  This obviously lowers perf.  

So in the general case fp16 might run back little slower, but the big caveat is if you're using hardware that has special instructions to accelerate fp16 matrix mults.  Currently this means you'd need to have a V100 (as in the aws p3 instance) or a Titan V.  If you have this hardware you should see a quite dramatic increase in performance for network  layers that are supported (for example fully connected layers).  If you don't have one of those gpus you're probably better off sticking with fp32 for training unless you're memory constrained

This seems to be related to a behavior that when converting nympy array to NDArray, it won't preserve dtype by default.

This worked for me:
```python
del mod
gc.collect()
# memory should be freed
```
